title: Space Force to industry: Prove value of new commercial space services
summary: Lt. Gen. Bratton: “We talk a lot about space refueling, but we don't really know what the case is for its military utility”

title: Companies offer proposals for Apophis asteroid missions
summary: Companies ranging from Blue Origin to a startup are proposing concepts for missions to visit an asteroid before it makes a very close flyby of Earth in five years.

title: New solar sail technology launches on Rocket Lab flight
summary: A potential new way to travel through space launched aboard Rocket Lab’s Electron rocket from Launch Complex 1 located on New Zealand’s Mahia Peninsula.

title: NASA confirms the Dragonfly mission to Saturn’s Moon: Titan
summary: NASA has given the final approval to proceed with the Dragonfly mission to Saturn’s Moon Titan with a launch scheduled for July...

title: China reorganizes its military, impacts likely for space operations
summary: China has established a new force of the People’s Liberation Army, with the reorganization to have repercussions for how its space forces are commanded.

title: NASA continues work on response to biological and physical sciences decadal survey
summary: NASA is continuing to refine its response to a decadal survey for biological and physical sciences in space, balancing ambitious science goals with limited budgets.

title: Daily Telescope: The ambiguously galactic duo
summary: Hubble continues to deliver the goods.

title: PLD Space raises funding to expand facilities for Miura 5 rocket
summary: Spanish company PLD Space has raised enough funding to embark on an expansion of production facilities for its small launch vehicle.

title: Launch Roundup: SpaceX lands its 300th booster, NASA tests a solar sail, and China launches three more taikonauts
summary: During the last full week of April, forthcoming launches include two Starlink missions planned on Monday and Friday, and another two more Falcon 9 flights lifting customer satellites. The first of these is the delayed WorldView Legion 1 & 2 mission which was originally due to fly last week and is now scheduled for Wednesday. The first Starlink mission of the week also saw another milestone reached with the 300th landing of a Falcon 9 booster on the Group 6-53 mission.

title: Pentagon eases cloak of secrecy around space warfare training
summary: Col. Christopher Fernengel, of the Space Force's Space Operations Command: ‘They're directing changes to declassify where it makes sense’
